sn22.153:1.2: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, does the view arise:
sn22.153:1.3: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”
sn22.153:1.4: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn22.153:1.5: “When form exists, because of grasping form and insisting on form, the view arises:
sn22.153:1.6: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.153:1.10: consciousness exists, because of grasping consciousness and insisting on consciousness, the view arises:
sn22.153:1.11: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine.’
sn22.153:1.15: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.153:1.17: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn22.153:1.18: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”
sn22.153:1.25: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.153:1.27: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would the view arise:
sn22.153:1.28: ‘I might not be, and it might not be mine. I will not be, and it will not be mine’?”
sn22.153:1.31: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
